title: Highlands punaré
text:
The highlands punaré, "Thrichomys inermis", is a <a href="Caviomorpha">caviomorph</a> rodent of <a href="South%20America">South America</a> from the <a href="Echimyidae">spiny rat</a> family. It is endemic to <a href="gallery%20forest">gallery forest</a>, <a href="savanna">savanna</a> and rocky outcrop habitats in <a href="Bahia">Bahia State</a> within the <a href="Caatinga">Caatinga</a> <a href="ecoregion">ecoregion</a> of eastern <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a> at elevations from 260 m to 1030 m. It sometimes nests and often takes refuge in crevices in rock formations, as means of both predator avoidance and moderating temperature extremes. The species tolerates a degree of habitat disturbance. Although hunted, it is considered common throughout its range. Its <a href="karyotype">karyotype</a> has <a href="Diploid">2n</a> = 26 and <a href="Fundamental%20number">FN</a> = 48.
The etymology of the species name corresponds to the <a href="Latin">Latin</a> word "<a href="wikt%3Ainermis%23Latin">inermis</a>" meaning "unarmed, defenceless" — itself constructed from the prefix "<a href="wikt%3Ain-%20-is%23Latin">in-</a>" meaning "without" and the stem "<a href="wikt%3Aarma%23Latin">arma</a>" meaning "defensive arms, armor" —, and refers to the soft fur of "Thrichomys" members replacing the spiny hair of the other genera of Echimyidae.
